org.orgName: District Court of the Third Judicial District of Washington

div1.p: In the District Court of the Third Judicial District of Washington Te ritory holding terms at Seattle King County s id Territory.
In the matter of the application of Alfred Woods for a Writ of Habeas Corpus.
To the honorable Roger S. Greene Judge of the above entitled court: The petition of Alfred Woods respectfully shows:
I. That he is unlawfully imprisoned, detained, confined and restrained of his liberty by one John H McGraw at the county jail in the city of Seattle, King County Washington Territory,

II. Tha thte cause or pretence if the restraint according to the best of the knowledge and belief of this applicant is this applicant's failure to give bonds for his appearance as a witness in a case now pending in said District Court wherein the United States is PALINTIFF and William Jameson et al defendants.

III. THat such imprisonment, detention, confinement and restaint are unlawful in this: That your petitioner is not confined upon any process issued upon any final judgment of any court, nor for contempt any court or officer or body having authority to commit. Nor upon a warrant issued from any court upon any indictment or information. That the said John H. McGraw has no warrant or process or authority of any kind to hold your petitioner.
And your petitioner respectfully shows that he is a poor person, that he has no money or property of any kind whatsoever, except the

sum of dollars and excepting the clothes which he now has on, which is of the value of five dollars. That it is impossible for him to raise any money or security of any kind or for him to deposity any money or other security except his personal recognizance for his appearance as a witness in said case. That he is a stranger in this community and that he has no friends or acquaintances in this territory that would enter into recognizance or signa bail bond for his appearance in said case and that it is impossible for him to obtain any such security.

Wherefore he prays that the writ of Habeas Corpus may be granted, directed to the said J. H. McGraw commanding him to have the body of your petitioner before your honor at a time and place therein to be specified, to do and receive what shall then and there be considered by your honor concerning him, together with the time and cause of his detention, and said writ; and that he may be restored to his liberty upon entering into personal recognizance in such sum as the court may direct for his a pearance in said cause. Dated this 24th day of October 1885 Alfred Woods Struve Haines & McMicken

Territory of Washington County of King SS Alfred Woods being first duly sworn on oath deposes and says: That he is the applicant named in the foregoing petition, that he has heard the same read, knows the contents thereof and that the same are true. Alfred Woods subscribed and sworn to before me this 24th day of October 1885 Maurice McMicken Notary Public
No 4669 Petition of Alfred Woods for Writ of Habeas Corpus
FILED OCT 24 1885 James Seavey, Clerk James P. Ludlow Deputy Clerk
Struve Haines and McMicken Attorneys At Law, Seattle . . . . W. T
